newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Polish poet Szymborska wins Nobel Literature Prize.
newsitem.headline: Polish poet Szymborska wins Nobel Literature Prize.

text.p: Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska won the 1996 Nobel Literature Prize, the Swedish Academy said on Thursday.

The academy said that Szymborska, 73, living in Krakow, won the prestigious award for her "poetry that with ironic precision allows the historical and biological context to come to light in fragments of human reality."
The award suprised observers, who had expected a novelist to win the $1.12 million award after Irish poet Seamus Heaney won last year's prize.

As well as being a poet, Szymborska has published book reviews and translations of French poetry. The academy said her handful of slim volumes of poetry were very difficult to translate because of their stylistic variety.
"With her distance and commitment, Szymborska accords full support to her idea that no questions are of such significance as those that are naive," the academy of Swedish academicians said.
From 1953 to 1981, Szymborska was on the editorial staff of the Polish intellectual magazine Zycie Literackie (Literary Life).
